abstract.text: A framework to allow integration of Nix devices into third party iOS and macOS applications.

inlineContent.text: This framework was written to allow integration of Nix devices into third party iOS and macOS applications. It provides tools to discover nearby Nix devices, open a connection, perform measurements, and obtain data. Tools are also provided for basic colour conversions and colour difference calculations.
framework. These two libraries should not be used together; remove the
library from your project before adding

Additional diagnostics are performed during the white tile scan on Spectro 2 type devices. As a result, the calibration command can now take 5 - 10 seconds to complete

content.text: Adding support for Nix devices to your Xcode project

inlineContent.text: Navigate to the General section of your project target
is included in the ‘Frameworks, Libraries, and Embedded Content’ section.
file. The value for these keys is a string shown presented to the user when the application requests permission to use the Bluetooth peripheral.
The wording of the string is up to you but should essentially state that ‘Bluetooth is required for connection to a Nix device’
Failure to add these strings will cause the app to crash when accessing the Bluetooth peripheral
from within Xcode, these keys correspond to the following entries:
For macOS projects, additional entries are required in the
Required for access to Nix device via Bluetooth

Required for SDK authentication (once per 30 day period)

The connection process is asynchronous and

Device operations are not possible until the
will be called with an appropriate status code indicating the cause of the error.
will also be called later whenever the device is disconnected. This can occur normally (i.e. - if the host device calls
), or abnormally (i.e. - if the connection is dropped due to an error or low Bluetooth signal strength).

The supplied framework binaries are linked to a specific allocation of Nix devices and will not operate with devices from another allocation. At connection time, the SDK will verify an allocation code stored on the Nix device. If this check does not pass, the SDK will contact a Nix authentication server to check if that device serial number is authorized. If the device cannot be authenticated (i.e. – an unknown allocation code was found and an internet connection is unavailable), the device will be disconnected with the status
. The internet connection is required only once every 30 days – once authorized, this status is saved, and connections can be made offline for this time period.
When the user has finished using the device, the connection can be closed using

code: // Device instance found by the DeviceScanner:
// Device properties can now be queried
// Handle status codes here, if desired in your application
// At a minimum should check for ERROR_UNAUTHORIZED status (see notes)
// Device not authorized for this SDK build
// Connection to Nix device timed out
// External power has been connected or disconnected

inlineContent.text: Once the device is connected and in an idle state, it is possible to take measurements:
to take measurements in all modes supported by the device. This is the recommended option.
to take measurement in only the specified scan modes. In most cases, this will not speed up the measurement cycle time, so this is not recommended.
The measurement operation is asynchronous and will return immediately. While the measurement is in progress, no other commands can be sent to the Nix device
Results of the measurement operation are provided in the
closure specified when starting the measurement. This closure provides two arguments:
A dictionary containing the measurement values as
objects. The keys of this dictionary correspond to the
below for notes on interpreting the measurement data.
The supported scan modes for a particular device are provided in the
list, or can be checked by calling

content.text: Performing in-field profiling / calibration with reference tile

inlineContent.text: Certain device types support in-field profiling or calibration using a provided reference tile. This process requires first decoding a string from the QR code attached to the reference tile and then directing the user to measure the same tile. Any necessary adjustments/corrections are performed internally by the SDK and/or the Nix device firmware itself.
The in-field calibration procedure may be performed as often or seldom as desired by the user. However, the property
flag indicates whether or not in-field calibration is recommended for the connected device.
This flag is updated after each regular measurement
This flag is determined automatically by both elapsed time and ambient temperature change
indicates whether or not a connected device supports this feature. The expected result by device are shown below:
Decode the QR code printed on the device reference tile and interpret as a string. Do not parse this data further.
Check if the parsed data is valid using
. If valid, continue to the next step.
Instruct the user to place the device on the reference tile.
Using the decoded tile string, run the in-field calibration routine using
This operation is asynchronous and returns immediately. While the operation is in progress, no other commands can be sent to the Nix device (wait for the callback)
will result in a closure with either a success or error code.

protocol defines other fixed properties that can be read once the device has connected and reached an idle state. These include, but are not limited to:
: status of external power connection / charging
: indicates whether or not this device provides spectral data
: indicates whether or not this device provides density data
: list of supported reference white values provided by the measurement data from this device
Measurements from Nix devices are provided as objects conforming to the
protocol. These contain all data and metadata to completely describe the measurement. Color, spectral, and density data are obtained from the
, respectively. The differences between these object types are listed below.

class provides many helpful functions for manual colour conversions and delta E calculations. This class was previously named
This document is not intended as an exhaustive reference. Please refer to the on-line documentation in the
section below for further details on the classes and methods provided by the Nix SDK. Example applications for iOS and macOS also provided in the SDK archive.
If you encounter any issues with SDK implementation, please contact us via:
Phone (Monday to Friday 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Eastern Time)

Limited anonymous usage data is tracked by the Nix SDK using Google Analytics. No personal user data is collected and no data which uniquely identifies an individual Nix device is collected. Collected data is subject to the Nix Apps privacy policy which is available at
. Events and usage data tracked by the Nix SDK are solely limited to the following information:
Device type (e.g. – Nix Pro, Nix Mini, etc)

Start field calibration using provided reference tile, if supported. Upon executing this command, the scan of the reference tile will begin immediately. The user MUST be prompted to place the device onto the reference tile BEFORE this method is executed. This method is asynchronous and will return immediately.
This command requires data from the reference tile QR code. As the format varies between different device types, the string data should be provided exactly as decoded from the QR code.
